notes.text:
Cardiology Fellow Admit Addendum
   Please see CCU resident admit  note for complete details of HPI, PMH,
   Medications, SH/FH.
   In brief, this is a 73f with a 6cm AAA, severe 3VD, failed CABG, s/p
   attempted PCI today notable for difficult R groin access, eventual
   engagement of the LMCA and attempted intervention on OM1 complicated by
   spiral dissection, fortunately without clear clinical consequences.
   Was stable on floor until BP dropped to 70s/40s and HR increased to
   100s, asymptomatic.  No CP.  Hct stable.  ECG unchanged.  Not in heart
   failure on exam.  Groin site benign, with  no flank bruising.  BP
   improved with IVF; currently comfortable in the CCU with HR 100, BP
   96/60.
   Stat TTE excluded significant pericardial effusion.  LV function looked
   grossly similar to prior study.  CT of abd/pelvis pending.
   Impression
   73F with extensive vascular history, now with asymptomatic
   fluid-responsive hypotension post PCI.  Clinically stable now although
   with resting tachycardia to 100.
   Awaiting CT to exclude bleeding.
   Given possibility of silent ischemia, would cycle cardiac biomarkers to
   help assess impact of OM intervention.
   Formal TTE in the morning may also be illustrative.
   If no obvious source for her lability and otherwise doing well, would
   give IV lopressor to keep HR <80.
   Further plans as detailed by admitting resident note.
   Case discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 4841**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 876**] notified via interventional
   fellow.
   [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 4157**], M.D.
   x90493
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I have also reviewed the notes of Dr(s). [**Name (NI) **], [**Doctor Last Name 7297**].
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   73 yr old woman with AAA who underwent abort CABG a few weeks ago and
   difficult PCI yesterday transferred to CCU for postPCI hypotension.
   Complete eval benign incl serial HCT, abd CT and echo.
   Better this AM.
   Physical Examination
   comfortable except for left arm pain (musculoskeletal)
   decr BS left base
   Medical Decision Making
   Continue to monitor.
   Awaiting IP to drain left pleural effusion MON.
   Above discussed extensively with patient.
   Total time spent on patient care: 30 minutes.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 174**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 4841**], MD
   on:[**2155-7-26**] 10:42 ------

Normal sinus rhythm, rate 89. Possible left atrial abnormality. Probable
inferior wall myocardial infarction of indeterminate age. Delayed precordial
R wave progression consistent with anterior wall myocardial infarction of
indeterminate age. Non-specific lateral repolarization changes consistent with
ischemia. Compared to the previous tracing of [**2155-7-9**] no significant change.

notes.text:
TITLE:
   Date of service: [**2155-7-26**]
   Initial visit, Cardiology service: CCU
   Presenting complaint: (Other: Hypotension, tachycardia)
   History of present illness: In brief, Ms. [**Known lastname **] is a 73 year old woman
   who has a history of coronary artery disease s/p a myocardial
   infarction in [**2131**] and a large abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Of note,
   approximately two months ago, the patient was undergoing pre-op
   evaluation and evaluation of chest pain prior to repair of a 6.6 cm AAA
   when she was noted to have an abnormal office EKG.  Following this, the
   patient underwent dobutamine stress test and was found to have
   upsloping ST segment depressions during the study, subsequently
   undergoing cardiac catherization on [**2155-6-13**] that revealed 3VD (mid LAD
   occlusion, 90% LCx, 100% Ostial RCA lesion).  The patient proceeded to
   CABG earlier this month but was unable to tolerate placement on bypass,
   and therefore was not revascularized and was maintained on medical
   therapy for her 3VD.
   .
   Two days prior to this admission, the patient presented to outpatient
   cardiology clinic complaining of dyspnea, and worsening DOE, which was
   felt to be an anginal equivalent.  Given her symptoms, she was admitted
   to [**Hospital1 5**] for further evaluation. On admission the patient was found to
   have a large left sided pleural effusion which was drained and found to
   be exudative.  She then underwent repeat elective cardiac catherization
   on [**2155-7-25**], however, cardiac catherization was complicated by a small
   sprial dissection of the OM1.  The patient was hemodynamically stable
   following her intervention and returned to the floor.  However, while
   on the floor the patient was noted to be hypotensive down to a systolic
   in the 70s and slightly more tachycardic to the low 100's (baseline
   80's-90's).  After an initial 500cc IVF bolus, the patient's SBP
   improved to the 100's but one hour later she was noted to have an SBP
   in the 70s once again.  Given her recent cardiac catherization there
   was concern for possible pericardial tamponade so a bedside TTE was
   performed which showed no significant pericardial effusion.  En route
   to the CCU, the patient was given an additional 500cc IVF bolus with
   improvement of her SBP to the low 100's and the patient continued to
   feel well with no symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath.
   Past medical history: CAD, s/p MI in [**2131**]
   CHF (EF 45-50%)
   Diabetes
   Hyperlipidemia
   Neuropathy
   Sciatica
   Asthma
   Bursitis of the right shoulder
   Rotator cuff tear, right shoulder
   Dry eyes
   H/O recurrent bronchitis
   Seasonal allergies
   GERD
   H/O Proteinuria in the past
   Squamous cell ca of the lip s/p resection
   Tonsillectomy
   S/P uvula removal
   Diverticulitis
   CAD Risk Factors
   CAD Risk Factors Present
   Diabetes mellitus, Dyslipidemia
   CAD Risk Factors Absent
   Hypertension, Family Hx of CAD, Family Hx of sudden cardiac death
   (Tobacco: Yes), (Quit: Yes), (Cigarettes: 1 packs / day x 80 yrs)
   Cardiovascular Procedural History
   PCI: Most recent: [**2155-7-25**]
   There is no history of:
   CABG: Grafts: Not tolerated
   Pacemaker / ICD
   Allergies:
   Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics)
   Unspecified [**Doctor First Name **]
   Flagyl (Oral) (Metronidazole)
   Diarrhea;
   Current medications: MEDICATIONS ON TRANSFER:
   Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY Start: In am
   Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY Start: In am
   Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H
   Rosuvastatin Calcium 20 mg PO DAILY
   Gabapentin 300 mg PO Q12H
   Acetaminophen 325 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain
   Duloxetine 30 mg PO DAILY Start: In am
   Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q6H:PRN constipation
   Insulin SC  (per Insulin Flowsheet)
   Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH [**Hospital1 **]
   Salmeterol Xinafoate Diskus (50 mcg) 1 INH IH Q12H
   Artificial Tears 1-2 DROP BOTH EYES PRN dry eyes

   Albuterol 0.083% Neb Soln 1 NEB IH Q4H:PRN SOB

Cardiology Fellow Admit Addendum
   Please see CCU resident admit  note for complete details of HPI, PMH,
   Medications, SH/FH.
   In brief, this is a 73f with a 6cm AAA, severe 3VD, failed CABG, s/p
   attempted PCI today notable for difficult R groin access, eventual
   engagement of the LMCA and attempted intervention on OM1 complicated by
   spiral dissection, fortunately without clear clinical consequences.
   Was stable on floor until BP dropped to 70s/40s and HR increased to
   100s, asymptomatic.  No CP.  Hct stable.  ECG unchanged.  Not in heart
   failure on exam.  Groin site benign, with  no flank bruising.  BP
   improved with IVF; currently comfortable in the CCU with HR 100, BP
   96/60.
   Stat TTE excluded significant pericardial effusion.  LV function looked
   grossly similar to prior study.  CT of abd/pelvis pending.
   Impression
   73F with extensive vascular history, now with asymptomatic
   fluid-responsive hypotension post PCI.  Clinically stable now although
   with resting tachycardia to 100.
   Awaiting CT to exclude bleeding.
   Given possibility of silent ischemia, would cycle cardiac biomarkers to
   help assess impact of OM intervention.
   Formal TTE in the morning may also be illustrative.
   If no obvious source for her lability and otherwise doing well, would
   give IV lopressor to keep HR <80.
   Further plans as detailed by admitting resident note.
   Case discussed with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 4841**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 876**] notified via interventional
   fellow.
   [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 4157**], M.D.

  arterial access
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  CT Abd/Pelvis to eval for RP bleed
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 WET READ: DXAe FRI [**2155-7-25**] 11:50 PM
  No RP bleed. AAA diameter is similar to [**2155-5-20**].
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  73 year-old woman with hypotension after cardiac catheterization
 on [**2155-7-9**] for evaluation of bleed.

 COMPARISON:  [**2155-5-20**].

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT-acquired images were obtained through the abdomen and pelvis
 without administration of oral or IV contrast.

 CT ABDOMEN: The lung bases demonstrate left greater than right small pleural
 effusions measuring simple fluid density (14 [**Doctor Last Name 137**]) and moderate associated
 relaxation atelectasis.  The lung bases are otherwise clear without
 consolidation or nodule.  There is moderate cardiomegaly. 3 x 1.3 cm
 epicardial collection (2:5) measuring fluid density likley represents post
 surgical change.

 On this non-contrast enhanced examination the pancreas, liver, gallbladder,
 spleen, and adrenals are unremarkable. Well circumscribed hypodense lesions
 better characterized as renal cysts on prior imaging are similar to [**2155-5-20**].
 There is no hydronephrosis.  An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with the
 largest diameter measuring 6.6 x 6 cm axially and diffuse calcifications with
 thick mural thrombus and an aneurysm in the thoracic aorta above the origin of
 the celiac trunk measuring up to 2.2 x 2 cm axially is unchanged since
 [**2155-5-20**]. The abdominal loops of large and small bowel are unremarkable without
 evidence of pneumatosis, free air, or obstruction. There is no mesenteric or
 retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.  There is no evidence of retroperitoneal
 bleed, free fluid, or free air.

 CT PELVIS:  The rectum and uterus are unremarkable.  A cystic lesion in the
 left adnexa measuring 2.9 x 2.8 cm likely represents a cyst and is unchanged
 since [**2155-5-20**].  Air within the bladder is likely secondary to Foley
 catheterization.  There is extensive sigmoid diverticulosis without evidence
 of diverticulitis.  There is no evidence of hematoma near the femoral vessels.

 Bone windows demonstrate no lesion concerning for metastasis or infection.
 Moderate multilevel degenerative changes, and S-shaped levoscoliosis centered
 in the lumbar spine is unchanged since [**2155-5-20**].

                                                             (Over)
